thread.title: Kenya: Fresh Policy On Processing of Animal Feeds in the Pipeline
thread.title_full: Kenya: Fresh Policy On Processing of Animal Feeds in the Pipeline

title: Kenya: Fresh Policy On Processing of Animal Feeds in the Pipeline
text:
Uganda: Kenya's Selfishness On Sugar Trade Is Not Good for Regional Integration 
Livestock Principal Secretary Prof Fred Segor said some manufacturers have been duping farmers with products that do not contain the nutrition levels that appear on their packaging. 
He said the policy will help the ministry streamline the industry and enforce standards stipulated by the Kenya Bureau of Standards (KEBS). 
"Currently, some manufacturers supplement nutritional contents and the percentages do not tally with the required standards in case this happens, Kebs should take action as the regulator," he told the Nation in an interview. 
Mr Segor said the policy will propose that manufacturers caught adulterating feeds either be stopped from business or face other penalties. 
The livestock PS said that Kenya was producing far less milk than South Africa, which has a fraction of the dairy cattle due to nutritional levels of feeds. 
ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION 
"We have four million exotic dairy cattle yet South Africa, which has less, produces a lot more milk," he said. 
The government also wants to address the issue of quality breeds and will set up liquid nitrogen plants across the country to store semen for Artificial Insemination (AI). 
Already, nitrogen plants used for cool storage have already been set up in Eldoret, Nyandarua and Meru. 
Mr Segor says two centres will be set up in this financial year in Sotik and Kirinyaga. 
He said the ministry wants AI extension officers in every ward across the country and would be looking to increase the 1,800 officers currently providing the service. 
Kenya's economy is predominantly based on agriculture. The industry accounts for approximately 27.3 per cent of Kenya's Gross Domestic Product and 60 per cent of export earnings. 
According to the Economic Survey 2015 released in April, the volume of milk increased from 523 million litres in 2013 to 541 million litres in 2014. Kenya
